articles.headline: Standing in the path of war, a small Ukrainian town braces as Russians advance.
articles.snippet: In Orikhiv, near the front lines, most residents have fled and those who remain endure constant shelling and the fear of what comes next.
articles.abstract: In Orikhiv, near the front lines, most residents have fled and those who remain endure constant shelling and the fear of what comes next.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORIKHIV, Ukraine — Squeezed between the Ukrainian and Russian front lines in an increasingly volatile battlefield in southeastern Ukraine, the small town of Orikhiv is constantly under fire, and Tamara Mikheenko, one of the few residents who remain, rarely leaves her basement.
articles.byline: By Michael Schwirtz and Lynsey Addario

articles.headline: Stocks drop 2.8%, led lower by tech, as April’s slump continues.
articles.snippet: Big technology companies are set to report earnings starting Tuesday. The S&P 500 has dropped nearly 8 percent this month, its worst monthly showing since March 2020.
articles.abstract: Big technology companies are set to report earnings starting Tuesday. The S&P 500 has dropped nearly 8 percent this month, its worst monthly showing since March 2020.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stocks slid on Tuesday, adding to a losing streak that has April shaping up to be Wall Street’s worst month in two years.

articles.headline: Selling Twitter to Elon Musk Is Good for Investors. What About the Public?
articles.snippet: The company’s decision to sell seems to have been based purely on the financials, with little if any regard for other stakeholders.
articles.abstract: The company’s decision to sell seems to have been based purely on the financials, with little if any regard for other stakeholders.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: The Biden Student Debt Question: Will He or Won’t He?
articles.snippet: Some advocates believe President Biden’s repeated extensions of the repayment pause, now set to end Aug. 31, could force his hand on loan forgiveness.
articles.abstract: Some advocates believe President Biden’s repeated extensions of the repayment pause, now set to end Aug. 31, could force his hand on loan forgiveness.
articles.lead_paragraph: Justin Nelson’s letter, one of the thousands that arrived at the White House this month, said he was proud to vote for President Biden back in 2020. Now he had a request: Would the president please honor a campaign promise and use the enclosed pen to wipe out thousands of dollars he owes in student loans?
articles.byline: By Stacy Cowley and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

articles.headline: As Diplomacy Hopes Dim, U.S. Marshals Allies to Furnish Long-Term Military Aid to Ukraine
articles.snippet: Germany said it would send Ukraine dozens of armored antiaircraft vehicles, a major shift for a country that has been reluctant to escalate the conflict with Russia.
articles.abstract: Germany said it would send Ukraine dozens of armored antiaircraft vehicles, a major shift for a country that has been reluctant to escalate the conflict with Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAMSTEIN AIR BASE, Germany — The United States marshaled 40 allies on Tuesday to furnish Ukraine with long-term military aid in what could become a protracted battle against the Russian invasion, and Germany said it would send dozens of armored antiaircraft vehicles. It was a major policy shift for a country that had wavered over fear of provoking Russia.
articles.byline: By John Ismay, Christopher F. Schuetze and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: Can Japan Keep the Lights On? The Ukraine War Upends a Big Energy Bet.
articles.snippet: The world’s third-largest economy has counted on imported liquefied natural gas as it shuts coal-fired plants and keeps nuclear sites closed. But Russia’s invasion has pushed prices sharply higher.
articles.abstract: The world’s third-largest economy has counted on imported liquefied natural gas as it shuts coal-fired plants and keeps nuclear sites closed. But Russia’s invasion has pushed prices sharply higher.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In 2018, when the power company Hope Energy entered Japan’s new retail electricity market, it thought it had a surefire strategy. Wholesale energy was becoming ever cheaper as liquefied natural gas flooded global markets. Hope Energy would sell competitively priced electricity contracts to local governments and public facilities, undercutting Japan’s old-line power companies, which had long prioritized stable supplies over cost.
articles.byline: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno

articles.headline: A Woman’s Haunting Disappearance Sparks Outrage in Mexico Over Gender Violence
articles.snippet: The case of Debanhi Escobar, 18, in Monterrey has ignited a national outcry over the government’s failure to deliver justice for missing women.
articles.abstract: The case of Debanhi Escobar, 18, in Monterrey has ignited a national outcry over the government’s failure to deliver justice for missing women.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONTERREY, Mexico — On the 13th day of searching for his missing daughter, Mario Escobar stood outside a gas station in the choking heat, clutching fliers with her photo and the vestiges of a desperate, lingering hope.
articles.byline: By Oscar Lopez and Alejandro Cegarra

articles.headline: Archegos stock manipulation scheme was ‘historic,’ U.S. attorney says.
articles.snippet: Manhattan federal prosecutors arrested and criminally charged the owner, Bill Hwang, and his former top lieutenant in one of the highest-profile Wall Street prosecutions in years.
articles.abstract: Manhattan federal prosecutors arrested and criminally charged the owner, Bill Hwang, and his former top lieutenant in one of the highest-profile Wall Street prosecutions in years.
articles.lead_paragraph: The sudden and stunning collapse of the once-obscure private investment firm Archegos Capital Management sent shock waves through the stock market last year and left Wall Street banks with $10 billion in losses almost overnight.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Lananh Nguyen

articles.headline: They Flooded Their Own Village, and Kept the Russians at Bay
articles.snippet: The waters that poured into Demydiv were one of many instances of Ukraine wreaking havoc on its own territory to slow Russia’s advance. Residents couldn’t be happier. “We saved Kyiv,” one said.
articles.abstract: The waters that poured into Demydiv were one of many instances of Ukraine wreaking havoc on its own territory to slow Russia’s advance. Residents couldn’t be happier. “We saved Kyiv,” one said.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEMYDIV, Ukraine — They pull up soggy linoleum from their floors, and fish potatoes and jars of pickles from submerged cellars. They hang out waterlogged rugs to dry in the pale spring sunshine.
